p: 15. The response. Our analysis has kept three things distinct:
1. usefulness: the being of the things that we initially meet;
2. objective presence: the being of things as encountered and determined by going through the useful things that we initially meet;
• as human being: we are the ontic condition that lets things be discovered as meaningful;
• as the “worldhood” or essence of the world of meaning.¶
The first two are categorial, i.e., they pertain to things that do not have ex-sistence. The third is an ex-sistential that determines our nature as engagement with meaning.

We could choose to understand the referrals that constitute meaningfulness-as-such as merely “a system of relations,” but such a formalization flattens out these referrals and misses their real experiential content. These supposedly “simple” relations (means-to-end, in-order-to, and the like) and their relata are in fact what constitute meaningfulness. Their experienced content resists mathematical functionalization. Nor are they not just “ideas” posited in “mere thinking.” Rather, these relations are where practical foresight actually lives and sustains itself.

We do not “volatize” the “substantial being” of the useful. On the contrary we provide the basis for understanding these things substantively, that is, in themselves. Only because things can be encountered as useful can they also be encountered as “just out there” in the form of “substances.” If taken as just objectively present, these relations might have their “properties” mathematically determined in “functional concepts.” But such concepts apply ontologically only to things whose being is taken as “substantiality.” Such functional concepts are formalized concepts that apply always and only to “substances.”
